verses.text: Wisdom has built her house; she has set up her seven pillars.
verses.comment: Here, Wisdom is personified. The 'seven pillars' may symbolize completeness or perfection, echoing themes of divine order—wisdom creates a secure foundation, much as the Church forms a spiritual house (see 1 Tim. 3:15). Early Christian interpreters saw Wisdom as a foreshadowing of Christ, who is the ultimate wisdom of God (1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: She has prepared her food, she has mixed her wine; she has set her table.
verses.comment: The act of preparing a banquet points forward to the messianic feast and may remind readers of sacramental imagery. The mixing of wine was a common ancient practice—perhaps hinting at the abundance of wisdom and spiritual nourishment provided by God (see Isa. 25:6).

verses.text: She has sent out her servant girls; she calls from the highest points of the city:
verses.comment: Wisdom actively seeks out all people, inviting them to her feast. The servants' proclamation echoes the universal call to salvation announced from the highest place for all to hear—a theme later fulfilled in the apostles' preaching (see Luke 14:16-23).

verses.text: "Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!" To the one without understanding she says,
verses.comment: Wisdom generously invites the naive and those lacking sense. This open invitation is significant—a reminder that God desires all to come to the knowledge of the truth (1 Tim. 2:3-4).

verses.text: "Come, eat my food, and drink the wine I have mixed."
verses.comment: This verse has deep sacramental overtones, especially in light of the Gospel—food and wine provided by Wisdom prefigure Jesus' offering of his Body and Blood as spiritual nourishment. Early believers read this as a type of the Lord's Supper, where Christ feeds the faithful with his true presence.

verses.text: "Leave behind your simple ways and live; walk in the way of understanding."
verses.comment: The invitation to abandon foolishness and choose life points toward true conversion and spiritual renewal—a call to transformation fulfilled through grace (see Eph. 4:22-24).

verses.text: Whoever corrects a scoffer gets insult for himself, and he who rebukes a wicked person receives abuse.
verses.comment: Not all are ready to receive correction. Jesus' teaching on not casting pearls before swine (Matt. 7:6) echoes this wisdom, stressing discernment in giving holy instruction.

verses.text: Do not reprove a scoffer, or he will hate you; reprove a wise person, and he will love you.
verses.comment: Correction is fruitful for the humble of heart. True wisdom welcomes discipline and sees it as an act of love and growth in righteousness.

verses.text: Give instruction to a wise person, and he will become wiser; teach a righteous person, and he will increase in learning.
verses.comment: Growth in wisdom is a continual process. Instruction deepens the righteousness and understanding of those living in the truth—a lifelong journey as disciples (see 2 Pet. 3:18).

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
verses.comment: Reverence for God is the foundation of all true wisdom. Knowing 'the Holy One' points to intimacy with God—who is revealed ultimately in Christ (John 17:3).

verses.text: For through me your days will be many, and years will be added to your life.
verses.comment: Long life is promised to those who embrace wisdom. This recalls the biblical connection between obedience and blessing—a principle affirmed by Christ (see Matt. 19:17).

verses.text: If you are wise, you are wise for yourself; if you scoff, you alone will bear it.
verses.comment: Each person is responsible for their response to wisdom. The fruit—whether blessing or folly—is personal and cannot be shifted to others.

verses.text: A foolish woman is chaotic; she is simple and knows nothing.
verses.comment: In contrast to Wisdom, Folly is personified as loud, seductive, and ignorant—an ever-present danger drawing others away from truth (see Sir. 9:13).

verses.text: She sits at the door of her house, on a seat at the heights of the city,
verses.comment: Folly also calls from the high places—rivaling Wisdom's invitation. Both the path of life and of death are announced publicly, highlighting human freedom to choose.

verses.text: Calling to those who pass by, who are going straight on their ways:
verses.comment: Folly specifically targets those set on the right path, tempting them away. The repetition underlines the constant spiritual battle—the need for vigilance and discernment.

verses.text: "Whoever is simple, let him turn in here!" To the one without understanding she says,
verses.comment: Folly's invitation closely mirrors that of Wisdom, underscoring the importance of discernment between truth and deception—echoed in Christ's warnings about false teachers (Matt. 24:24).

verses.text: "Stolen water is sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant."
verses.comment: Sin is often deceptively attractive. The fleeting pleasure of stolen goods contrasts with the enduring satisfaction of wisdom. The theme prefigures Jesus’ teaching that life’s true bread is found only in him (John 6:35).

verses.text: But he does not know that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
verses.comment: The path of folly leads to death and separation from God—a dire warning. Spiritual death is the ultimate result of rejecting wisdom, but the way of life remains open to those who heed the call.
